H0.text: Infrared is the part of the electromagnetic spectrum that the 2001 NASA probe observes and records to investigate very low‑energy radiation emitted when the universe began.

H1.text: Microwave is the part of the electromagnetic spectrum that the 2001 NASA probe observes and records when investigating very low‑energy radiation emitted at the beginning of the universe.

H2.text: Ultraviolet is the part of the electromagnetic spectrum that the 2001 NASA probe observes and records to investigate very low‑energy radiation emitted when the universe began.

H3.text: Visible is the part of the electromagnetic spectrum that the 2001 NASA probe observes and records to investigate very low-energy radiation emitted when the universe began.

A4.text: The WMAP instrument uses five frequency bands from 22 GHz to 90 GHz to facilitate rejection of foreground signals from our own Galaxy.
